channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Spying Bill in Australia Stirs Fears of Anti-Chinese Backlash
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia with Premier Li Keqiang of China in Sydney in March. Mr. Turnbull says proposals to curb foreign influence are not explicitly aimed at China, or Australia’s Chinese community.
item.description: Australia wants to curb Chinese government influence in its democracy, but Chinese-Australians worry the new legislation will unfairly single them out.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Russia and China Object to New ‘America First’ Security Doctrine
item.media:description: President Trump presented a blueprint for the United States’ national security on Monday and warned of rising threats from Russia and China.
item.description: Russian and Chinese officials criticized President Trump’s new national security doctrine for its emphasis on American exceptionalism.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Halting Auction, France Designates Marquis de Sade Manuscript a ‘National Treasure’
item.media:description: The original manuscript of “120 Days of Sodom, or The School of Libertinage,” by the Marquis de Sade.
item.description: The designation blocks, for now, any sale of “120 Days of Sodom,” one of the aristocrat’s most notorious works, to a foreign buyer.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Montreal Journal: Calling Poutine ‘Canadian’ Gives Some in Quebec Indigestion
item.media:description: “Now that poutine has become an international superstar,” Nicolas Fabien-Ouellet said, “Canadians want to say it is theirs, but it is not.”
item.media:credit: Alexi Hobbs for The New York Times
item.description: A culture war over French fries, cheese curds and brown gravy grips Quebec.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Rebels in Yemen Fire Second Ballistic Missile at Saudi Capital
item.media:description: Customers at a coffee shop in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, looking at a cloud of smoke in the sky on Tuesday. Yemeni rebels said they had fired a missile at a royal palace in the city.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: Saudi Arabia said its air defenses had taken down a rocket aimed at residential areas, while the rebels said they had been targeting a royal palace.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Peru President Could Be Biggest Figure Yet to Fall in Latin America Graft Scandal
item.media:description: President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski of Peru in Lima, Peru, on Sunday.
item.description: The president, Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski, will have an hour on Thursday to defend himself when impeachment proceedings open.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: A Year After the Berlin Market Attack, Germany Admits Mistakes
item.media:description: A memorial site to honor the victims of last year’s Christmas market terrorist attack in Berlin opened on Tuesday.
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel spoke of “concerted determination to improve” after criticism of the government’s response.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: In Polio’s Worst-Hit District, Vaccinators Strain for Access
item.media:description: Health workers vaccinating children against polio in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in September. The district of Shahwalikot in Kandahar Province has had four of the world’s 17 new polio cases this year.
item.media:credit: Muhammad Sadiq/EFE, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Out of 20 polio cases globally in 2017, four appeared in one Afghan district where United Nations health officials plead with all sides to cooperate.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: As Signs of a Mass Grave Emerge, Myanmar Cracks Down
item.media:description: A satellite image of the Inn Din village in Rakhine State, Myanmar, on Nov. 10. The military commander said an investigation was underway into “people being killed and buried” in a cemetery there.
item.description: The military concedes that corpses were found where Rohingya have been massacred but reporters investigating the killings remained under arrest.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and SAW NANG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: After Street Clashes, Argentina’s Congress Passes Pension Overhaul
item.media:description: Protesters on Tuesday outside Congress in Buenos Aires. Scores have been arrested or injured during demonstrations.
item.description: The intensity of opposition to a tightening of pension benefits underscored how hard it will be for President Mauricio Macri to accelerate reforms.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: South Sudan Army Makes Push Against Rebels as Peace Talks Begin
item.media:description: South Sudanese refugees crossing into Uganda in June. More than two million people have fled the country for Uganda, Democratic Republic of Congo and other nations, the largest national exodus in Africa in 20 years.
item.description: The army marched into the town of Lasu in the country’s southwest, capturing a rebel headquarters.
item.dc:creator: JASON PATINKIN and JINA MOORE

item.title: Is France the Latest Front in Russia’s Information War With the West?
item.media:description: The news studio at RT France, in Boulogne-Billancourt, near Paris, on Monday.
item.description: With the launch of RT France, the Kremlin-backed network aims to provide what it calls alternative points of view.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: How the Saudi Blockade Is Starving Yemen
item.description: Yemen is on the brink of famine. One of the poorest countries in the Middle East and riven by conflict, it is now practically sealed off from the world by a sea and air blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Fans Mourn Kim Jong-hyun, a K-Pop Singer Whose Style Was Instantly Recognizable
item.media:description: A memorial outside a hospital in Seoul on Tuesday for Kim Jong-hyun, whose suicide devastated many K-pop fans.
item.description: The death this week of the musician, from the K-pop group SHINee, set off mourning by bereaved fans. He had left a note speaking of depression.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Decoding Trump’s Plan to Rein In China
item.media:description: President Trump introducing the White House’s national security report in Washington on Monday. The report included details of China’s rising technological prowess.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills The New York Times
item.description: Beijing poses a threat on the business and technology fronts as well as militarily, the White House argues in a new national security blueprint.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: China Unveils an Ambitious Plan to Curb Climate Change Emissions
item.media:description: The Chinese public, coping with pollution like this in Shanghai last year, has grown increasingly worried about environmental issues like smog, water quality and soil pollution.
item.description: The world’s No. 1 polluter will create a national market to clean up its power sector, putting it in a leading position on the issue as the U.S. retreats.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and LISA FRIEDMAN
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: Mexican Women Brutalized by Police Hope Day of Reckoning Is Near
item.media:description: Norma Aidé Jiménez Osorio testifying before the Inter-American Court of Human Rights in San José, Costa Rica, last month. She and 10 others accuse Mexican police officers of sexual abuse and torture.
item.description: A decade-long struggle by 11 women who were sexually attacked and tortured by officers in San Salvador Atenco has cast a shadow over Mexico’s president.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Did Russia Meddle in Brexit? A Social Media Study Casts Doubt
item.media:description: Rallying last year in London for Britain to leave the European Union. Researchers are questioning whether the Kremlin used social media to support the move, as presumed.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Oxford researchers join Facebook and Twitter in questioning whether Moscow used social platforms to nudge Britain out of Europe. But suspicions remain.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Republican Party, Amtrak, Yemen: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Chile’s Election Consolidates Latin America’s Rightward Shift
item.media:description: Sebastián Piñera and his wife, Cecilia Morel, celebrating his victory in the Chilean presidential election outside a hotel in Santiago.
item.description: The vote was the left’s final shot to hold on to power in one of the region’s economic and diplomatic heavyweights.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO, PASCALE BONNEFOY and DANIEL POLITI

item.title: In Bangladesh, New York Subway Bomb Suspect Reached Out to Rohingya
item.media:description: The Kensington section of Brooklyn is a hub for the Bangladeshi immigrant community in New York. Bangladeshi and American investigators say Akayed Ullah, who is accused of trying to set off a bomb in a Manhattan subway station, was radicalized in the United States.
item.description: The suspect in the attempted New York subway attack last week rode a bus across Bangladesh to help Rohingya refugees. Was he following Al Qaeda or his heart?
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 19 Acts of Heroism in 2017
item.media:description: Alok Madasani, left, and Ian Grillot, right, survivors of the February shooting at Austins Bar and Grill in Olathe, Kan., were recognized this month in Topeka by the state’s House speaker, Ron Ryckman Jr.
item.description: Many unheralded moments of courage, altruism and sacrifice lurk behind news stories. Here are some of our favorites.
item.dc:creator: MILLIE TRAN and DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Trump, Amtrak, Instant Pot: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Our Journalists Share Their Most Memorable Interviews of 2017
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Times reporters reflect on the conversations that stuck with them long after their assignments ended.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by INSIDER STAFF

item.title: My Most Memorable Interview / 2017: Rules for Reporting a Planned Death: No Photos, No Pad, No Pen
item.media:description: The author on the hill above John Shields’s home the day after his death. At the bottom of the hill, beneath a tent and a blanket, his body rested on a gurney in his backyard.
item.description: All attention needed to support John Shields’s spirit as it began its journey. A detached witness would distract from that. If I was in the room I had to participate.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Grenfell Fire Inquiry Finds U.K. Construction Rules Dangerously Lax
item.media:description: The remains of Grenfell Tower, seen behind residential buildings in west London last week.
item.description: Six months after the deadly blaze, a report to Parliament said there was a culture of “doing things cheaply.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Austria’s New Government: A Mix of Far-Right, Pro-Europe and Youth
item.media:description: President Alexander Van der Bellen of Austria, center, and Sebastian Kurz, Austria’s new chancellor, center right, at the swearing-in ceremony of the new government in Vienna, on Monday.
item.description: The new chancellor, Sebastian Kurz, is now Europe’s youngest leader after joining forces with the Freedom Party, founded by neo-Nazis after World War II.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Rome Journal: Unearthed in Rome’s New Subway: Extinct Elephants and Persian Peach Pits
item.media:description: The excavation site of what will be the last stop along Rome’s new subway line, at the Forum. The stop was moved from its original location at Piazza Venezia after important artifacts were discovered.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: The construction of a subway line to central Rome has illuminated the city’s past in extraordinary detail through archaeology.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Afghan President Fires a Powerful Governor From Post He Held 13 Years
item.media:description: Atta Muhammad Noor in 2010. Mr. Noor is part of a generation of former warlords who saw their regional fortunes fluctuate over the past decade.
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.description: The removal of the former warlord Atta Muhammad Noor, who had amassed great wealth, could further fray the struggling coalition government.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: Cyril Ramaphosa Wins A.N.C. Leadership Battle in South Africa
item.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa during the African National Congress conference in Johannesburg on Saturday.
item.description: The wealthy businessman and former Mandela protégé is now in position to succeed Jacob Zuma as president of the country.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Uber Driver in Lebanon Arrested in Killing of Rebecca Dykes
item.media:description: Rebecca Dykes, a British diplomat, was killed over the weekend after she left a party in Beirut.
item.media:credit: The Foreign and Commonwealth Office, via Reuters
item.description: Ms. Dykes, a British diplomat, was found dead on Saturday after leaving a party in Beirut. Uber said it was helping with the investigation.
item.dc:creator: MARK A. WALSH

item.title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution Condemning Move on Jerusalem
item.media:description: A United Nations Security Council meeting on Jerusalem this month. The council’s longtime view has been that no country should establish an embassy in Jerusalem.
item.description: As the United States used its veto to block the Security Council resolution, the 14-to-1 vote underscored the Trump’s isolation on a central issue in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Military Fires Upon Intruder at Air Base in Britain
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Mildenhall air base in England. It is used by the United States Air Force as well as the Royal Air Force.
item.description: The Mildenhall air base, about 75 miles northeast of London, is used by the United States Air Force. A suspect is in custody.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Ikea Is Focus of European Inquiry Over Possible Skirting of Tax Bills
item.media:description: European antitrust officials are looking into whether tax rulings in the Netherlands gave an unfair advantage to a division of Ikea.
item.description: The European Commission is concerned that tax rulings in the Netherlands may have allowed the Swedish furniture retailer to pay fewer taxes and to gain an advantage.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: In India, Modi’s Party Shows Its Might in State Elections
item.media:description: Supporters of the Bharatiya Janata Party celebrating in Ahmedabad, India, on Monday after Gujarat State election results were announced.
item.description: Voters in Gujarat and Himachal Pradesh showed that the Bharatiya Janata Party of Prime Minister Narendra Modi was still a formidable political force.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Retrospective: The International Herald Tribune
item.description: Highlights and curiosities from The International Herald Tribune’s storied reportage.

item.title: American Who Escaped Crowded Bali Prison Is Recaptured
item.media:description: Chrishan Beasley on Monday at Kerobokan Prison after his recapture.
item.media:credit: Badung Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Chrishan Beasley, a Californian held on drug charges, was seized outside a hotel on a neighboring island in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON

item.title: Artist Who Filmed Beijing Crackdown Is Reportedly Freed on Bail
item.media:description: The painter Hua Yong in one of his videos documenting the evictions from migrant neighborhoods in Beijing.
item.description: Hua Yong had recorded the city’s campaign to expel migrant workers in short videos and said in one of his last clips that his arrest was imminent.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: British Embassy Worker in Beirut Found Strangled
item.media:description: Rebecca Dykes, a Briton who was a staff member at the British embassy in Lebanon, was found strangled Saturday by the side of a road east of Beirut, the Lebanese capital.
item.media:credit: Britain's Foreign and Commonwealth Office, via Associated Press
item.description: The woman, identified as Rebecca Dykes, was found strangled near a highway outside Beirut, a Lebanese security official said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Turkey Plans Embassy in East Jerusalem, Erdogan Says
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, following President Trump’s example, said he would move his country’s embassy to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.
item.description: The announcement by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan came as Muslim leaders call for world leaders to recognize East Jerusalem as Palestine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Honduran President Declared Winner, but O.A.S. Calls for New Election
item.media:description: President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras addressed his supporters in Tegucigalpa this month.
item.description: The response from the O.A.S., arguing that the vote was riddled with irregularities, was likely to escalate the political crisis in Honduras.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Toronto Buzzes With Talk of Billionaire Couple’s Suspicious Death
item.media:description: Police officers canvassing neighbors for information outside the Toronto home of Barry and Honey Sherman, who were found dead under circumstances that the police described as “suspicious.”
item.description: Family and friends of the generic-drug mogul Barry Sherman and his wife, Honey, say someone killed them and made it look like a murder-suicide.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Tropical Storm Kills 30, and Nearly 90,000 Flee to Shelters in Philippines
item.media:description: A flooded street in easterm Samar, Philippines, on Saturday.
item.description: Tropical Storm Kai-Tak unleashed floods and landslides, and stranded thousands of holiday travelers.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: U.K.’s Next Brexit Agony: What Sort of Trade Deal?
item.media:description: Britain’s chief Brexit negotiator, David Davis, left, and Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, second-left, in talks in Brussels on Dec. 8 with European Union officials.
item.description: Britain’s next step will be as divisive as any. It must decide whether to model future ties with the European Union on Norway, Canada, a Canada-Singapore hybrid or something else.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: C.I.A. Helped Thwart Terrorist Attack in Russia, Kremlin Says
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at an annual news conference in Moscow last week.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin called President Trump on Sunday to thank him for the help disrupting an ISIS attack in St. Petersburg.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Disputes Delay Vote on African National Congress Leader
item.media:description: Supporters of Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa’s deputy president, outside the African National Congress annual conference in Johannesburg on Sunday.
item.description: South African officials said 400 delegates had been disqualified. The results on a successor to President Jacob Zuma as party leader were expected on Monday.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Beirut Journal: Lebanon’s Palestinian Refugees Resist from the Sidelines
item.media:description: The Shatila refugee camp in Beirut, Lebanon, a tangle of markets, construction and electrical wires. More than 450,000 of five million registered Palestinian refugees worldwide live in Lebanon.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Caught between resistance and resignation, the displaced are struggling with the implications of President Trump’s decision on Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: NADA HOMSI
